results.title: Bill Onus campaigns ‘Vote Yes for Aboriginal Rights’
results.credit_line: Courtesy AAP Image / National Library of Australia
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. He helped establish the Aborigines Advancement League and campaigned for the ‘YES’ vote in the 1967 Referendum.
results.title_for_label: Bill Onus campaigns ‘Vote Yes for Aboriginal Rights’
results.description: Bill Onus, President of the Victorian Aborigines’ Advancement League (right), participating as the only Aboriginal in the march for Aboriginal Rights referendum on May 29, 1967.
description_for_label: Bill Onus, President of the Victorian Aborigines’ Advancement League (right), participating as the only Aboriginal in the march for Aboriginal Rights referendum on May 29, 1967.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy AAP Image / National Library of Australia

results.title: Alcheringa cast and crew
results.credit_line: Courtesy ABC Library Sales / National Archives of Australia
results.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy ABC Library Sales / National Archives of Australia

results.title: ‘How to throw a boomerang’ leaflet
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.

results.title: Mao Tse Tung
results.creator_credit: Alan Landsburg, David L. Wolper and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biography”.
Traces Mao Tse Tung’s life from his birth in Hunan Province, 1893, to becoming leader of Communist China. In 1920 he set out to gain control of China, in 1949 he proclaimed the birth of the communist regime in China. Shows how he gained leadership, banished Chiang Kai-Shek and his armies from the mainland, fought the U.N. forces to a stalemate on the 38th parallel, and presented a challenge to the western world. Narrated by Mike Wallace.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Landsburg, David L. Wolper and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: John Barrymore
results.creator_credit: David L. Wolper and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biography”.
Portrays events in the life of film and theatre idol John Barrymore, using photographs and film footage. An excellent, insightful and refreshingly unsentimental biography. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Joseph Stalin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biography”.
Depicts the life of Stalin, under whose strong-arm rule the USSR became a world power. Explains Stalin’s part in making Russia a communist state. Commentary by Mike Wallace. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Mussolini
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biography”.
Traces the life of Mussolini from his youth to the development of his own party and the Munich conference with Hitler. Shows his arrest and exile, capture and shooting. Introduced by Mussolini’s son and narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Two faces of Gove
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Looks at the situation at Gove, after the 1971 Land Rights Case, in which Naalco were given clear title to the lease. Considers the effect of the decision on the people of Yirrakala. Construction workers talk about their attitudes and relations with the Aborigines. Shows social life and bauxite mining procedures.
